Idiom (Louisiana Creole): Pa vann po bef-la avan ou trapé li
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Don’t celebrate or make plans before achieving success.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Don’t count your chickens before they hatch.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common among Louisiana Creole hunters and traders in colonial times.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Louisiana C: [pa van po bɛf la avɑ̃ u trape li]
First Example Sentence: Li di mo: ‘Pa vann po bef-la avan ou trapé li,’ paské mo té tro pressé.
Second Example Sentence: Granpapa toujou répété sa lè nou fè plan san réfléchi.
Third Example Sentence: Mo aprann pa fè sa apré mo pèdi on bon opòtinité.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: People think others have it better than they do.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: People are often dissatisfied with what they have.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Adaptation of French proverb; common in rural Louisiana speech.
First Example Sentence: Mo kouzin kwè zèb lakay toujou pli vè, mé li pa sav difikilté yo.
Second Example Sentence: Yo toujou gadé lòt moun é di zèb lakay toujou pli vè.
Third Example Sentence: Nan travay-la, moun toujou panse lòt gen pi bon pos.

Idiom (Louisiana Creole): Kouyon pa janmen manké nan lari
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause; negation with indefinite subject
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: There will always be someone gullible.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Street proverb from Creole-speaking New Orleans neighborhoods.
First Example Sentence: Yo di kouyon pa janmen manké nan lari, é sa vré!
Second Example Sentence: Toujou ni on moun ki ka kwè tout sa yo tande.
Third Example Sentence: Kouyon pa janmen manké nan lari, mé yo toujou ri apré.

Idiom (Louisiana Creole): Dlo dòmi, pa dòmi anba li
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause; imperative and subordinate clause
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Don’t underestimate calm situations; danger may be hidden.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Stay cautious even when things seem peaceful.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from river metaphors in plantation-era Louisiana.
First Example Sentence: Granmanman té toujou di: ‘Dlo dòmi, pa dòmi anba li.’
Second Example Sentence: Li sanblé kalm, mé dlo dòmi, pa dòmi anba li.
Third Example Sentence: Sa sé on bon konsèy pou lavi: dlo dòmi, pa dòmi anba li.

Idiom (Louisiana Creole): Pèsonn pa pli gran pas bondyé
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: No one is greater than God.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common expression in Catholic Creole communities of Louisiana.
First Example Sentence: Mo granmè toujou di pèsonn pa pli gran pas bondyé.
Second Example Sentence: Lè ou nan pwoblèm, sonjé pèsonn pa pli gran pas bondyé.
Third Example Sentence: Yo kwè nan pawòl-la: pèsonn pa pli gran pas bondyé.

Idiom (Louisiana Creole): On bon zanmi sé on trésò
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A good friend is a treasure.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Widely used in Creole oral traditions across Louisiana parishes.
First Example Sentence: Yo toujou di on bon zanmi sé on trésò, é mo kwè sa.
Second Example Sentence: Li montré mo sa, paské li toujou la pou mo.
Third Example Sentence: On bon zanmi sé on trésò, mé sé pa fasil pou jwenn yo.

Idiom (Louisiana Creole): Kouté, pa tann, sé sa ki fè moun pèdi tèt yo
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Compound clause with infinitive and negative imperative
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Acting before listening leads to mistakes.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: From oral teaching traditions in Creole-speaking schools.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Louisiana C: [kute pa tɑ̃ se sa ki fɛ mun pɛdi tɛt jo]
First Example Sentence: Granpapa di: ‘Kouté, pa tann, sé sa ki fè moun pèdi tèt yo.’
Second Example Sentence: Nou aprann nan lavi, kouté, pa tann, sé sa ki fè moun pèdi tèt yo.
Third Example Sentence: Li té fè erè paské li pa kouté avan li aji.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Time is valuable and should not be wasted.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Adapted from English expression 'Time is money', localized in Louisiana Creole commerce.
First Example Sentence: Chef-la toujou di tan sé lajan pou motivé nou.
Second Example Sentence: Nan travay, mo aprann byen: tan sé lajan.
Third Example Sentence: Nou pé pa pèdi tan, paské tan sé lajan.

Idiom (Louisiana Creole): Sé an jou lapli, an jou soley
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Sometimes good days, sometimes bad days.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Metaphor rooted in Louisiana weather and farming communities.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Louisiana C: [se ɑ̃ ʒu lapli ɑ̃ ʒu sɔlɛj]
First Example Sentence: Li di mo, sé an jou lapli, an jou soley, é mo souri.
Second Example Sentence: Nou ka aprann aksepte tout sa: sé an jou lapli, an jou soley.
Third Example Sentence: Lavi sé kon sa: sé an jou lapli, an jou soley.

Idiom (Louisiana Creole): Fè doubout, menm lè van ka souflé fò
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Stand firm even when facing difficulties.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used in resistance songs during the Louisiana Creole cultural revival.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Louisiana C: [fɛ dubut mɛm lɛ vɑ̃ ka sufle fɔ]
First Example Sentence: Yo toujou di: fè doubout, menm lè van ka souflé fò.
Second Example Sentence: Li rété fò, paské li konprann: fè doubout, menm lè van ka souflé fò.
Third Example Sentence: Mo toujou sonjé pawòl sa lè lavi difisil.
